data.text:
Welcome to the four hundred and forty-seventh of my blog interviews with novelists, poets, short story authors, biographers, agents, publishers and more. Today‚Äôs is with thriller and children‚Äôs fantasy author Philip Caveney. A list of interviewees (blogged and scheduled) can be found here. If you like what you read, please do go and investigate further.

Morgen: Hello, Philip. Please tell us something about yourself, where you‚Äôre based, and how you came to be a writer.

Philip: I‚Äôm an author of both children‚Äôs and adult‚Äôs fiction. I live in Heaton Moor, near Manchester in the UK. I started writing when I was a teenager, after being blown away by Ray Bradbury‚Äôs fabulous fantasy novel Something Wicked This Way Comes.

Morgen: I‚Äôve heard of it but never read it‚Ä¶ I clearly should. üôÇ What genre do you generally write and have you considered other genres?

Philip: My adult works are thrillers and my children‚Äôs books (which are considerably more successful), are in the fantasy genre.

Morgen: That‚Äôs really interesting; that your children‚Äôs books are more successful, I guess there‚Äôs less competition? What have you had published to-date?

Philip: I‚Äôve published over twenty books during my career. Best know to American audiences are the Sebastian Darke adventures, featuring a half-elvish, half-human wannabe jester. They‚Äôve sold all over the world.

Morgen: They do sound fun. üôÇ Have you had any rejections? If so, how do you deal with them?

Philip: All authors get rejections. You have to develop a thick skin and push on regardless. It always helps to remind yourself that a rejection is generally the result of one person‚Äôs opinion.

Morgen: Absolutely. Have you won or been shortlisted in any competitions?

Philip: I‚Äôve been shortlisted for quite a few book prizes in the UK, but have yet to actually win one. Always the bridesmaid, never the bride!

Morgen: Yet‚Ä¶ üôÇ Do you have an agent?

Philip: I don‚Äôt currently use an agent, though I have a various points in my career. (I invariably fall out with them over something!)

Morgen: Oh dear‚Ä¶ I fear I might be the same‚Ä¶ I eBook my work because I love having control, although I‚Äôm sure I would respect a good agent‚Äôs expertise. Do you think they‚Äôre vital to an author‚Äôs success?

Philip: I think for a first book, an agent can really help to get your work read.

Morgen: I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre right‚Ä¶ especially with getting a top publisher. I mentioned eBooks, are your books available as eBooks? Were you involved in that process at all? Do you read eBooks or is it paper all the way?

Philip: All my children‚Äôs books are available as eBooks, including one, The Talent, that is ONLY available as an eBook. Eight of my out-of-print adult thrillers were published earlier this month.

Morgen: How exciting. üôÇ How much of the marketing do you do for your published works or indeed for yourself as a ‚Äòbrand‚Äô?

Philip: If it‚Äôs a traditionally published book (which it usually is) I leave that side of things to the publisher, though I do love to go out to schools and libraries to promote the children‚Äôs books. The Talent is slightly different. Since I published it myself via kindle direct, I am investigating many different avenues in an attempt to spread the word.

Morgen: Social networking seems to be the key, although interspersed with ‚Äòuseful‚Äô or ‚Äòinformative‚Äô tweets about something else. Do you have a favourite of your books or characters? If any of your books were made into films, who would you have as the leading actor/s?

Philip: My latest book, Night On Terror Island, is under consideration by a major Hollywood production company. I would love to see Max Von Sydow play the character of Mr Lazarus. Other than that, it would be a cast of unknowns.

Morgen: Oh yes, I like him. üôÇ Did you have any say in the titles / covers of your books? How important do you think they are?

Philip: Covers are really important and I‚Äôm fortunate enough to get good ones!

Morgen: They are very striking. What are you working on at the moment / next?

Philip: I‚Äôm writing a book called Space Blasters, which is the third book in my Movie Maniacs series. It follows Night On Terror Island and Spy Another Day.

Morgen: Do you manage to write every day? Do you ever suffer from writer‚Äôs block?

Philip: I write most days, but do spend quite a bit of time visiting schools and so forth. I have never (thankfully) suffered from writer‚Äôs block!

Morgen: Me neither but then I don‚Äôt stick to genre and it sounds as if you have enough variety too. Do you plot your stories or do you just get an idea and run with it?

Philip: These days I create the characters, put them in a background and let things happen. It‚Äôs almost as if the characters themselves come up with the plot!

Morgen: They do, and that‚Äôs my favourite aspect of writing. Do you have a method for creating your characters, their names and what do you think makes them believable?

Philip: I just imagine them and the names come more or less automatically. I spend a lot of time inhabiting them, it‚Äôs a kind of role play.

Morgen: üôÇ Do you write any poetry?

Philip: I rarely write poetry. To be honest, it‚Äôs a completely different technique to writing fiction and it‚Äôs probably my weakest asset.

Morgen: Oh me too ‚Äì I say I don‚Äôt ‚Äúget it‚Äù but then I‚Äôve never been taught (or read it) so that doesn‚Äôt help. Do you write any non-fiction or short stories?

Philip: I‚Äôve done a lot of short stories, which have appeared here and there, but never managed to get a collection off the ground, which is a shame, because I love the form. For non-fiction I write film and restaurant reviews.

Morgen: It is a shame, they‚Äôre my favourite form but hard to sell (although I probably don‚Äôt market them well enough). Do you do a lot of editing or do you find that as time goes on your writing is more fully-formed?

Philip: It‚Äôs certainly more fully-formed than it used to be, but I give every book at least three drafts.

Morgen: Do you have to do much research?

Philip: Only for the Alec Devlin books. These were set in the 1920‚Äôs and concerned ancient civilizations, so the research had to be spot on.

Morgen: It does because there will always be an ‚Äòexpert‚Äô out there only too eager to point out inaccuracies. üôÇ What point of view do you find most to your liking: first person or third person? Have you ever tried second person?

Philip: I‚Äôve written in both the third and first person, and like them both, but not everything works in first person. The second person I‚Äôm less comfortable with.

Morgen: That‚Äôs not really surprising as you write novels ‚Äì it‚Äôs my favourite viewpoint but I write very short pieces which suits second person better; Sunday‚Äôs 5pm fiction piece was just 44 words). üôÇ Do you have pieces of work that you think will never see light of day?

Philip: Not now we have kindle direct! There are quite a few unsold manuscripts tucked away that for one reason or another, didn‚Äôt quite make it past the finishing post ‚Äì so in time, they WILL be published.

Morgen: I hope so too with mine ‚Äì with practice it‚Äôs easier to go back and see what‚Äôs wrong. What‚Äôs your favourite / least favourite aspect of your writing life? Has anything surprised you?

Philip: The time everything takes! The book I‚Äôm writing now won‚Äôt see publication until May 2013. I used to fondly imagine that you finished a book on Monday and it was in the shops by Friday!

Morgen: üôÇ It can be when self-publishing eBooks‚Ä¶ although not in the shops but online seems to be the way everything‚Äôs headed. What advice would you give aspiring writers?

Philip: Two things. If you want it more than anything else, then never give up. And, don‚Äôt be afraid to rewrite. The worst that can happen is your book will be a little bit better ‚Äì the best that can happen is that it will be brilliant.

Morgen: üôÇ If you could invite three people from any era to dinner, who would you choose and what would you cook (or hide the takeaway containers)?

Philip: I hate this question!

Morgen: Oh dear‚Ä¶ sorry about that. üôÇ

Philip: I‚Äôd invite the first three names that occurred to me at the time and I‚Äôd cook king prawn linguine (my speciality).

Morgen: Nice. Is there a word, phrase or quote you like?

Philip: ‚ÄòYes I can.‚Äô

Morgen: üôÇ Are you involved in anything else writing-related other than actual writing or marketing of your writing?

Philip: I run a writers group in my hometown called Writers Inc ‚Äì and I do a day a week at a University (currently Lancaster) teaching writing skills on behalf of the Royal Literary Fund.

Morgen: I‚Äôve not heard of the Royal Literary Fund before‚Ä¶ What do you do when you‚Äôre not writing? Any hobbies or party tricks? üôÇ

Philip: I go to the cinema ‚Äì a lot! I don‚Äôt have any tricks worth mentioning.

Morgen: üôÇ Are there any writing-related books that you find useful?

Philip: Books on how to write aren‚Äôt very useful in my experience. The only one I thought was of any use was Stephen King‚Äôs On Writing.

Morgen: A very popular choice in these interviews. Are you on any forums or networking sites? If so, how valuable do you find them?

Philip: When ‚ÄòThe Talent‚Äô came out, I joined a lot of blogging sites, thinking I could promote it there. But of course, I got lots of other writers (and, it must be said, would-be writers) trying to sell me their books!

Morgen: Sadly that happens a lot. I think many writers realise how strong the competition is and think by shouting the loudest they‚Äôll get spotted but it doesn‚Äôt work like that. What do you think the future holds for a writer?

Philip: I think the future is looking rather bleak for anyone who actually wants to make money from their writing. The book industry is currently going through what happened to the music industry with the onset of digital publishing.

Morgen: Where can we find out about you and your work?

Philip: Just Google my name! Or, go to my websites: http://philip-caveney.co.uk and www.writers-inc.org.uk.

Morgen: Is there anything else you‚Äôd like to mention?

Philip: I‚Äôm a good speaker and I love doing school visits!

Morgen: Two-thirds of this blog‚Äôs traffic is generally from the US, the rest mainly the UK so let‚Äôs hope you have some offers. üôÇ Is there anything you‚Äôd like to ask me?

Philip: How‚Äôs the weather where you are?

Morgen: One I‚Äôve not been asked before here‚Ä¶ üôÇ Mixed today; light / dark clouds and blue sky‚Ä¶ typical English summer; can‚Äôt make up its mind. Thank you for chatting with me today, Philip.

I then invited Philip to include a synopsis of his latest book‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs the scariest movie ever ‚Äì and they‚Äôre stuck in it!

Kip‚Äôs father owns an old fashioned cinema, the Paramount Picture Palace ‚Äì but when the regular projectionist retires, his place is taken by Mr Lazarus, a mysterious old man who has devoted his life to the cinema. He has also invented The Lazarus Enigma ‚Äì an incredible machine that can take a person and put them into any film. When Kip‚Äôs little sister Rose finds herself accidentally lost in monster movie Terror Island, Kip and his friend Beth have to go in to rescue her. While they are in the film, everything is real ‚Äì real Neanderthals, real giant serpents, real sabre toothed tigers‚Ä¶ and they have been warned that they have to escape before the final credits roll ‚Äì otherwise they‚Äôll be trapped in there forever‚Ä¶

Update December 2012: Since we did the interview, Philip tells me‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúNight On Terror Island has been shortlisted for four book prizes and actually won the Oldham Brilliant Books Award. (Yay!) I have also released a sequel, Spy Another Day (in which Kip and Beth are sent into a Bond-style movie) and most recently, I released a historical time travel thriller called Crow Boy, set in Mary King‚Äôs Close, Edinburgh. We had an exciting launch down under the streets of the city and I‚Äôm enclosing one of the spooky photographs we took down there! (I‚Äôm actually the one on the left).‚Äù

Congratulations, Philip!

***

If you are reading this and you write, in whatever genre, and are thinking ‚Äúooh, I‚Äôd like to do this‚Äù then you can‚Ä¶ just email me and I‚Äôll send you the information. They do now (January 2013) carry a fee (¬£10 / ‚Ç¨12.50 / $15) for the new interviews on this blog but everything else (see Opportunities on this blog) is free.

If you go for the interview, it‚Äôs very simple; I send you a questionnaire (I have them for novelists, short story authors, children‚Äôs authors, non-fiction authors, and poets). You complete the questions, and I let you know when it‚Äôs going to go live. Before it does so, I add in comments as if we‚Äôre chatting, and then they get posted. When that‚Äôs done, I email you with the link so you can share it with your corner of the literary world. And if you have a writing-related blog / podcast and would like to interview me‚Ä¶ let me know.

Alternatively, if you‚Äôd like a free Q&A-only interview, I now have http://morgensauthorinterviews.wordpress.com on which I‚Äôve rerun the original interviews posted here then posted new interviews which I then reblog here. These interviews are Q&A only, so I don‚Äôt add in my comments but they do get exposure on both sites.
